instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board had some corrosion near <CAPACITOR>C2951</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> after removing the short on <CAPACITOR>C2951</CAPACITOR> I noticed diode mode reading was lower compared to a working board on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> was only 1.5V, after inspecting with thermal cam I found <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> was getting hot, replaced it and now all I get is 0.300V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

Rails present:
ppbus 8.56V 
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

After that all S4 rails are missing

Im a little lost on this one, any help will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Board is bootlooping every 4-5 seconds,  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> shows up on every boot loop but I cannot seem to get it to pulse because it only last for about 1 second.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"Board is bootlooping every 4-5 seconds"
VCORE pulses then?
Also check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Try starting in SMC bypass mode too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes VCORE and pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulse, SMC bypass I get 2 fan spins for about 2 seconds each separated by 1 second then board goes back to 0.004a and stays there, the boot loop does not alway happen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Inspect for corrosion near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/01.
Check all SPi Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
You may need to clean/remove J6100.

Reball SMC, as basic step for corroded boards.
Try known good BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> and tried new BIOS, removed J6100 and reballed SMC, in fact the reballing of the SMC was done early in the troubleshooting steps and nothing, I give up.
